user_request: A poem where the speaker hears America singing, each worker their own song.

revision_history.draft:
She peels the latex down past wrists that know
their own circumference. The basin fills
with what it takes to clean a face they won't
remember morning, and her nails drag
light from each bead that gathers there,
reclaiming them like coins.

The hallway clock ticks without purpose.
Somewhere a door closes with finality—
not drama but the end of one corridor's
quiet negotiation with the gurney it produces.
She holds her breath until the glass
clouds just enough to read the name
she'll never call out. The gown she wears
has pooled at her ankles, and she pushes it
back up with a motion that could almost
be dancing if she weren't so focused
on where the next towel is.

There's a rhythm to this building after hours:
the sink's slow clank each time she sets down
a basin full; the gauze she tears with one clean hand,
folding it into nothing anyone would keep.
Her shoes click on the tile in a tempo
she has matched to breathing, forty-two times
per minute, the body's lullaby
she sings to rooms that need disinfection.

Someone left a window open. The cold
finds her shift jacket like a second sleeve,
and she buttons it further even though
the buttons are already all the way up.
The gown rides again. She smooths it down
with both hands, which is superfluous—
but also: this is what hands do when
the work asks only for repetition
and the body answers with precision.

Morning will arrive for someone. A nurse station
has a coffee station has a thermos going,
and someone's already poured themselves a cup.
She notices it. She could reach across the counter.
The water in her bucket is getting warm.
But there is method to her carrying it back
to the sink, setting it down with two fingers,
wringing the cloth she's been using
on everything that touches him—his blood
collecting now in a small river on the sheet,
and beneath it, the mattress turning slightly
each time his body shifts its weight.

She has not named this song.
No one has. The hallway empties further.
A light in another wing goes dead for seven seconds,
comes back, goes again—some flicker
beyond her pay grade, beyond the building's skin.
Her gloves crack where the thumb meets fingertips.
She notes this too: where they're wearing thin.

He will be moved soon. She can hear the trolley
arriving down the corridor like a breath held
then released. The gurney comes with its own nurse,
efficient in green, already talking to him
in the voice that softens after a while
into almost-friendship—*okay, okay, we got you.*

For now she wipes his neck again.
The towel catches salt where it shouldn't be,
and she presses harder than necessary,
which is also: this is what hands do
when asked to stay still. The water pools.
She dunks the cloth back in the basin,
rinses under the faucet with one hand,
the other holding steady on his shoulder blade.

No one will sing this version.
The thermos keeps running. Somewhere a phone
is ringing and not being picked up—just sound,
just frequency, just the building's itch
to organize itself into something called morning.
Her shoes click off down the corridor,
each heel a note too high for any melody,
just percussion, just the fact of weight
leaving tile, leaving more tile, leaving
the last room she touches with her thumbprint,

which is also: this is what fingers know—
how to smear, how to almost-erase,
how to make a name look like it was never meant.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The poem has genuine structural intelligence. The "also" technique — where a sentence performs double work, both functional and emotional — is well-developed. It creates a texture of repetition that mirrors the labor itself rather than decorating it.

**Line 25-30** is the strongest passage:
> Her shoes click off down the corridor,
> each heel a note too high for any melody,
> just percussion, just the fact of weight
> leaving tile, leaving more tile, leaving
> the last room she touches with her thumbprint.

The final image — "her thumbprint" on a surface that has been left behind — earns its abstraction because it arrives after so much concrete detail. The "leaving" sequence (tile/weight/tile/last room) is genuinely propulsive and rhythmic, mimicking the laboring body's own awareness of retreat.

**Line 15-20** also works:
> A light in another wing goes dead for seven seconds,
> comes back, goes again—some flicker
> beyond her pay grade, beyond the building's skin.
The technical detail (the timing) and the refusal to interpret it emotionally are precise. That's a poem listening.

The entire second half of the draft is stronger than the first half — lines 15-32 contain more alive language than everything before line 14 combined. The shift from morning setup into actual labor at around line 10 is well-placed.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché and stock language (lines 1-8):**
> She peels the latex down past wrists that know
> their own circumference. The basin fills
> with what it takes to clean a face they won't
> remember morning, and her nails drag
> light from each bead that gathers there,
> reclaiming them like coins.

"Peels the latex down," "nails dragging light," "reclaiming them like coins" — this is decorative. The poem is better off in its strongest mode (lines 15+) when it stops explaining and starts recording. Direction: cut or radically compress lines 1-8 to get closer to the second half's density of observation.

**Abstraction creeping back in (lines 9, 23):**
> A hallway clock ticks without purpose.
> Someone left a window open. The cold
> finds her shift jacket like a second sleeve,
> and she pushes it up with a motion that could almost
> be dancing if she weren't so focused
> on where the next towel is.

"Without purpose" — this tells the reader what to think about silence. "Could almost be dancing" is pure paraphrase, not image. Direction: replace both of these with observed detail. What does the clock actually look like? What does pushing up her sleeve *look* like?

revision_history.draft:
She peels the latex down past wrists that know
their own circumference. The basin fills
with what it takes to clean a face they won't
remember morning, and her nails drag
light from each bead that gathers there,
reclaiming them like coins.

The hallway clock ticks—
its round silver hand pushing through dark numbers.
Somewhere a door closes with finality:
not drama but the end of one corridor's
quiet negotiation with the gurney it produces.
She holds her breath until the glass
clouds just enough to read the name
she'll never call out. The gown she wears
has pooled at her ankles, and she pushes it
back up with a motion that could almost
be dancing if she weren't so focused
on where the next towel is.

There's a rhythm to this building after hours:
the sink's slow clank each time she sets down
a basin full; the gauze she tears with one clean hand,
folding it into nothing anyone would keep.
Her shoes click on the tile in a tempo
she has matched to breathing, forty-two times
per minute, the body's lullaby
she sings to rooms that need disinfection.

Someone left a window open. The cold
finds her shift jacket like a second sleeve,
and she buttons it further until the sound of click
is final, even though the last button was already home.
The gown rides again. She smooths it down
with both hands, which is superfluous—
but also: this is what hands do when
the work asks only for repetition
and the body answers with precision.

He will be moved soon. The trolley arrives
like a breath held then released,
its own nurse already talking to him
in the voice that softens after a while
into almost-friendship—*okay, okay, we got you.*

For now she wipes his neck again.
The towel catches salt where it shouldn't be,
and she presses harder than necessary,
which is also: this is what hands do
when asked to stay still. The water pools.
She dunks the cloth back in the basin,
rinses under the faucet with one hand,
the other holding steady on his shoulder blade.

No one will sing this version.
The thermos keeps running. Somewhere a phone
is ringing and not being picked up—just sound,
just frequency, just the building's itch
to organize itself into something called morning.
Her shoes click off down the corridor,
each heel a note too high for any melody,
just percussion, just the fact of weight
leaving tile, leaving more tile, leaving
the last room she touches with her thumbprint—
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The second half of the draft (roughly lines 15-32) is where the poem lives. The "also" technique — sentences that do double work, both functional and emotional — is genuinely well-executed here:

> She smooths it down with both hands, which is superfluous—
> but also: this is what hands do when
> the work asks only for repetition
> and the body answers with precision.

The line earns its "also" because the first half of each sentence is mundane observation (smooths, pushes up her sleeve), while the second half names a strange, almost philosophical truth about labor. That mode is the poem's engine.

Lines 25-30 are the strongest:

> Her shoes click off down the corridor,
> each heel a note too high for any melody,
> just percussion, just the fact of weight
> leaving tile, leaving more tile, leaving
> the last room she touches with her thumbprint,

"Leaving tile / leaving more tile" is genuinely propulsive and rhythmic — it mimics what's being described. The final image (her fingerprint on a surface that has been vacated) arrives after so much concrete detail that it lands without explanation.

Line 28-30 also works:

> A light in another wing goes dead for seven seconds,
> comes back, goes again—some flicker
> beyond her pay grade, beyond the building's skin.

The technical observation (seven-second cycle) is precise. The refusal to interpret it emotionally is what makes it a poem listening rather than reporting sentiment.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Lines 1-8: Decorative setup that doesn't earn its place.**

> She peels the latex down past wrists that know
> their own circumference. The basin fills
> with what it takes to clean a face they won't
> remember morning, and her nails drag
> light from each bead that gathers there,
> reclaiming them like coins.

"Peeling latex," "nails dragging light," "reclaiming them like coins" — this is ornamental. The poem's strongest mode of observation (lines 15+) is already present in lines 9-20, so the first eight lines are pure setup that doesn't discover anything the later sections don't already do.

**Direction:** Cut or radically compress lines 1-8 to get closer to line 9. The poem opens too slowly and explains itself before it starts recording.

---

**Lines 9-14: Abstraction and paraphrase creeping in.**

> A hallway clock ticks—
> its round silver hand pushing through dark numbers.
> Somewhere a door closes with finality:
> not drama but the end of one corridor's
> quiet negotiation with the gurney it produces.
> She

revision_history.draft:
She peels the latex down past wrists that know
their own circumference. The basin fills
with what it takes to clean a face they won't
remember morning — and her nails drag
light from each bead that gathers there,
reclaiming them like coins.

His name on the trolley's transfer sheet.
The gurney scrapes the linoleum
the way a match drags off its head —
a thin, particular sound she memorizes
because no one else will. The hallway window
holds its silver wedge all night,
and somewhere down the hall a monitor
ticks like a bird on a single syllable.

She holds her breath until the glass
clouds into unreadability.

The gown has pooled at her ankles.
She pushes it up with both hands — superfluous,
but also: this is what hands do when
the work asks only for repetition and the body answers
with precision. Her shoes click on the tile
in a tempo she's matched to forty-two breaths per minute,
her own lullaby, though no one hums it.

Someone left a window open. The cold
finds her shift jacket like a second sleeve.
She buttons the third button until the sound of click
is final — the last button wasn't necessary,
but she does things fully. Her shoes click off down the corridor,
each heel a note too high for any melody,
just percussion, just the fact of weight leaving tile.

His neck is saltier than the rest.
She presses harder than necessary,
which is also: this is what hands do
when asked to stay still. The water pools.
She dunks the cloth back in the basin,
rinses under the faucet with one hand,
the other holding steady on his shoulder blade.

Somewhere a monitor stops its beep for seven seconds,
then restarts — that flicker, that small
disobedience of light beyond her pay grade,
beyond the building's skin. She notices because
she doesn't have anything else to notice.

No one will sing this version.
The thermos keeps running. Somewhere a phone
is ringing and not being picked up—just sound,
just frequency, just the building's itch
to organize itself into something called morning.

Her shoes click off down the corridor,
each heel a note too high for any melody,
until she reaches the room where no one sleeps,

and the light in another wing goes dead for seven seconds,
comes back, goes again — some flicker beyond her pay grade,
beyond the building's skin.

final_poem:
His name on the trolley's transfer sheet.
The gurney scrapes linoleum — a thin, particular sound
she memorizes because no one else will. The hallway window
holds its silver wedge all night,
and somewhere down the hall a monitor
ticks like a bird on a single syllable.

She holds her breath until the glass
clouds into unreadability.

The gown has pooled at her ankles.
She pushes it up with both hands — superfluous,
but also: this is what hands do when the work asks only for repetition and the body answers
with precision. Her shoes click on the tile
in a tempo she's matched to forty-two breaths per minute,
her own lullaby, though no one hums it.

Someone left a window open. The cold
finds her shift jacket like a second sleeve.
She buttons the third button until the sound of click
is final — the last button wasn't necessary,
but she does things fully. Her shoes click off down the corridor,
each heel a note too high for any melody,
just percussion, just the fact of weight leaving tile.

His neck is saltier than the rest.
She presses harder than necessary,
which is also: this is what hands do
when asked to stay still. The water pools.
She dunks the cloth back in the basin,
rinses under the faucet with one hand,
the other holding steady on his shoulder blade.

Somewhere a monitor stops its beep for seven seconds,
then restarts — that flicker, that small
disobedience of light beyond her pay grade,
beyond the building's skin. She notices because
she doesn't have anything else to notice.

No one will sing this version.
The thermos keeps running. Somewhere a phone
is ringing and not being picked up—just sound,
just frequency, just the building's itch
to organize itself into something called morning.

Her shoes click off down the corridor,
each heel a note too high for any melody,
until she reaches the room where no one sleeps,

and the light in another wing goes dead for seven seconds,
comes back, goes again — some flicker beyond her pay grade,
beyond the building's skin.
